comments.text:
+akenzua bambam Thing about singularities that people often forget is that 
it takes time for the black hole to collapse into a singularity. As it 
collapses, the density becomes greater and so the gravitational field at 
the centre (not outside of coerce). The missing part of the equation is 
time distortion. More density = more gravitational pull = more time 
distortion. The black hole reaching infinite density would take an infinite 
amount of time observed from the outside. After close to infinite time all 
the matter in the universe would collapse into a single black hole and only 
then when all the matter in the universe comes together to form a 
singularity will an actual singularity form. Of coerce we do not know what 
will happen in such an great distance of time away, though we can 
speculate. I do not see anywhere else where the "Schwarzshcild solution" 
could become a reality and it may even be prevented from happening due to 
unforeseen physical events. Maybe as the singularity is forming all mass is 
converted from matter to energy and thus the gravitational field disappears 
and the energy is released... Who knows...

I think it's safe to say that the "Schwarzshcild solution" is 
mathematically correct, but it does not take all physical qualities into 
account. It just says that in these conditions this will happen. It does 
not say that these conditions will ever come into play in reality. Until we 
have a theory of everything we should be careful of predictions that do not 
account for all conditions.
comments.author: GeneralBlackNorway

comments.text:
+SparkySywer
First, black holes do have infinite gravity, you just have to be careful to 
clarify what it is that is actually infinite. The gravitational field at 
distance created by the black hole is normal for its mass. 

The problem arises when you get to the singularity that forms a black hole. 
Riemann curvature tensor of the manifold becomes infinite; gravity becomes 
infinite in a black hole, only at its singularity. Not sure where you heard 
what you said in your question, but General Relativity predicts this. It is 
called the Schwarzshcild solution. This is one specific case that shows GR 
is truly incomplete, infinities in a physical theory of reality are a 
no-no. please do research before stating facts on youtube
comments.author: akenzua bambam

comments.text:
Correct, The event horizon doesn't actually have really, anything. The 
singularity has infinite density.
comments.author: Atrius

comments.text:
+akenzua bambam Black holes' event horizons do not have infinite gravity.

Also, gravity doesn't increase with density, gravity on the surface of an 
object increases when the surface is closer to the center.

comments.text:
+Ajay Kumar Singh Do you want me to give you a number? If so i have to 
disappoint you, i do not know the exact number of animals that can perceive 
colour.
What I do know is that the ability to differntiate between different 
wavelenghts of electromegnetic waves is a widespread phenomena that you can 
find in almost any strain of eukoryota although the wavelenghts that are 
detected differ greatly.
But even disregarding that, "colour" is not an innate property of light. 
What we call colour is the product of our brain efforting the electric 
signals coming from our eyes. We have no way of discerning what the world 
looks like for a brain different than ours assuming "look" is the right 
expression. Therefore the question if other animals see "colours" is 
ill-formulated. A better formulation would be: "Can they detect different 
wavelenghts of electromagnetic waves?"
comments.author: KingQwertzlbrmpf

comments.text:
+Ajay Kumar Singh You are simply wrong assuming that only humans can see 
colours. The mantis shrimp has the most advanced and most powerful 
colour-perception system in all of the known world. His eyes have 14 
different types of lightsensitive cells for different wavelengths and 
thereby different colours. Just for a quick comparison, humans have only 3 
types of such cells. The eyes of the mantis shrimp can also detect 
ultraviolet and polarised electromagnetic waves. Even more amazing, each of 
his two complexeyes is composed of up to 10.000 miniscule mirco-eyes that 
are arranged in such a clever pattern that each complexeye is able to 
perform 3D perception on his own. That means the mantis shrimp is able to 
use one eye to target potential prey while the other eye is on lookout duty 
for other predators.
Bottomline: No, humans are not the only animals that can see colours and 
they do not even have the best colour perception.

more simplistic agricultural style that is more earth friendly, but that

comments.author: Jordan Kyriakou

comments.text:
I agree that modern agriculture consumes a lot of energy, but as xbb1024 
said, we are more efficient. The same plot of land in an undeveloped nation 
probably couldn't produce as much yield or have the capacity to harvest 
such quantities of food. It's like saying your computer consumes much more 
energy than your calculator, but your computer has the capacity to perform 
much more complex tasks. Your “returns” far exceed the cost. If modern 
agriculture produced negligible gains in yield and harvest, then I would 
agree with you.

Its also worth keeping in mind that even though modern agriculture does 
have its down-sides (as you mentioned herbicide and pesticide production, 
mechanization, irrigation etc etc causing eutrophication, herb/pesticide 
resistance, ground and surface water contamination), there really aren't 
that many good alternatives. Yes the Haber process does take a lot of 
energy, but that allows for the production of food. Without man-made 
fertilizer, food would be much more scarce and famine would be prevalent. 
The only solution to such issues of feeding the planet without the use of 
modern agricultural techniques would be forced population control.
comments.author: Jordan Kyriakou

comments.text:
+xbb1024 Efficient per unit area used, yes, but if you measure by energy

world's annual energy supply), herbicide and pesticide production, 
mechanization, irrigation etc etc causing eutrophication, herb/pesticide 
resistance, ground and surface water contamination, colony collapse 
disorder etc etc not too mention linking food prices with rising oil 
prices...

top_comment.text:
Isn't it technically impossible to show what anything would look like in 
frequencies outside of the human range? If you were to show what an image 
looked like in, say, ultraviolet only, you would still have to use colors 
within our own frequencies in order for us to see it. By using those 
colors, you're effectively using colors outside of the ultraviolet 
frequency, which means that it's not an accurate representation of an 
"ultraviolet only" view of an object.

Or, a better example, dogs can only see reds and blues (I think), but if 
you tried to show a dog the greens that humans can see (such as on grass), 
you can only use a combination of the reds and blues to represent it. Thus 
what you show the dog still isn't an accurate representation of what humans 
see.﻿
top_comment.author: Marcus McLin

the lens of electromagnetic radiation our eyes can't normally detect.

the light we see with the other imperceptible light objects emit.

You should pay more attention in class.

top_comment.text:
The reason North was created was because of 2 main things. Magnetic and 
true north. Magnetic north is basically where a compass always points to 
(well in the southern hemisphere it points South but the Compass and maps 
were mainly used by northern civilizations). 

true north is the position the earth is relative to the sun and the axis 
that the Earth spins on. An old sailing technique is using a scale to 
compare the angle of the Horizon with the Noon sun (The highest point the 
sun is in the sky), this creates a certain amount of degrees. On the true 
equator the Sun is almost directly above you at 0 degrees. In say New York 
the sun is actually more on the southern part of the sky with a horizon 
angle of about 42 degrees (This is why latitude coordinates use angular 
degrees). Both of these are very different.

Interesting right? Magnetic north and true north poles are actually 
hundreds of miles apart.﻿
top_comment.author: milkduds1001

comments.text:
+mazehazeglaze Actually, it points to the South Pole. This is because the 
Earths poles are the strongest magnetic point on the planet. That's the 
reason aura lights only happen closer to the poles, because the magnetic 
field is strong enough on those places to interact with charged particles 
from the Sun.

It points south in the southern hemisphere because when you cross the 
equator heading south you get closer to the southern pole, the magnetic 
energy from the southern pole becomes stronger than the northern one and so 
it points south. Compasses point to the strongest magnetic influence and in 
the south that is the south pole. The reason we have north as north is 
because a majority of modern 1ST world countries originated in the northern 
hemisphere. Sumeria, Greece, Rome, China, England, the US etc, most of the 
greatest civilizations and societies that ever lived have been in the 
Northern hemisphere, which is why the map is the orientation it is today.

top_comment.text:
I'm skeptical on the idea that "up = better, so therefore let's put north 
on the top of our maps." I think it more likely that, somehow, at some 
point, for some reason, it became standard to think "up = north," and, 
then, after the fact, after up = north maps were standard, then the idea 
that up = north = better got subconsciously, discursively, wrapped up in 
that.

After all, think about who was making these maps. If it was the Portuguese, 
and if they thought up was better, why would they put the heathen 
Protestant England above them on the map? Why not flip it around? Portugal, 
Italy (Rome), Ancient Egypt... none of these places are especially 
northerly. It's not as if the Scandinavians or Scots were the chief peoples 
designing world maps in the 15th-16th centuries.﻿

comments.text:
+RavianGale Time is really hard to explain, but our perception of it 
passing in 'seconds' and 'minutes' is subjective. We only percieve time one 
slice at a time, rather than the whole that it really is. 

Based on what I understand of the theory of the Ten Dimensions, the idea is 
like this. If one dimension is just a single line, to create a second 
dimension, we stack these lines on top of each other in either direction to 
create a plane. The third dimension follows the same rule, stacking these 
planes (think of them as sheets of paper) up and down creates three 
dimensions, the way we percieve the world. If a creature that was only made 
of two dimensions, and only percieved two dimensions traveled in three 
dimensions, he would only see one sheet of paper at a time. However, 
because he is in three dimensions, he is free to rotate any direction he 
pleases. The same is true for the fourth dimension. It is an infinite 
number of three-dimensional existences stacked up upon each other. Seeing 
as we only exist in three dimensions, we are able to move freely in the 
fourth dimension, but can only perceive it one slice at a time. 

Working upwards, there are ten theoretical dimensions making up reality as 
we know it, created by different possible origins of the universe and 
different possible 'dimensions' housing other 'realities'. If you want to 
know more from people who have actual degrees on the topic, just look 
around you tube for videos uploaded by universities and their students (be 
sure it's reputable though.) I'm no expert, so feel free to correct me if 
you see I've made a mistake!
comments.author: Philippe Haussmann

Hey vsauce, I have a burning question for the next video: if energy cannot 
be created or destroyed, only transformed, how does energy used in 
processes in the human body transform after someone dies (excluding the 
fact that all energy is transformed at least a little into thermal energy). 
Also, what work is being done by the dead body for it to keep that energy, 
considering the fact that energy is the ability to do work, and is the 
Higgs Boson going to constantly release the same energy, or may that 
transform as well? That last question is going too far into the more 
recent, and abstract, modern physics concept, so I'm sorry if it's hard to 
answer.﻿
top_comment.author: Alex “AlexAvenger” Smith

comments.text:
+Errol Dow I do understand that thermal energy cannot be excluded, and I 
just now realized that the rest of the body will oxidize, thanks to you, 
that does give the answer to my question. As for my use of the word 
"abstract," I meant to use it in the more rhetorical term, which actually 
does mean complex; I just wanted to use a different word other than 
complex. Also, I am a bit uneducated of the Higgs; however, I was speaking 
of the energy that used to actually "find" it in March of last year now, 
something like that, right? Anyways, apparently all that I've learn of it 
(that it gives mass to objects and it's the reason why some matter can be 
passed through each other) may have actually been either not clarified, or 
simply wrong. I know it does have to do with mass; however, due to the 
source of the information stating that it was the "God particle," it leads 
me to believe that it follows the exaggerations used in the one book, the 
name escapes me, however. Anyways, I am bit uneducated on the higgs, so 
forgive me for that.
comments.author: Alex “AlexAvenger” Smith

comments.text:
Any energy contained within a dead body is lost as heat radiated into the 
surrounding atmosphere.  Without living cells there is no new heat added to 
the system hence why dead bodies become cold (well at least as cold as the 
ambient temperature).  I know you said, "excluding the fact that all energy 
is transformed at least a little into thermal energy" but that cannot be 
excluded.  The rest of the body will be left to oxidize and break down into 
more stable atomic components.  Higgs bosons do not radiate energy per se, 
they actually do not exist in the current universe independent of the higgs 
field of which they are part (except within the extreme conditions present 
within a super collider and even then only for the briefest of moments).

comments.text:
He did a video on it.  Lol
Well a quick answer is the earth will continue going in a relatively 
straight line tangent to where it is in its orbit.  The earth would 
probably be pulled around via other celestial bodies' gravity and given an 
infinitely large universe it would eventually hit something.  It might also 
get captured by another star and orbit it.  The earth would be under 
constant night and temperatures will drop to well below zero.  Basically 
life would cease to exist after a few "years".
Let's just hope that our sun doesn't spontaneously get sucked into a 
wormhole or something.

comments.text:
+BelkoConkersAll 
i'm familiar with most of the material that's talked about on this channel. 
so it'd have to be our shared sources that are lying - in which case 
nothing. it doesn't matter. it doesn't affect my life whether there is or 
isn't an electromagnetic spectrum. if my phone works by magic and prayer or 
by some carefully calculated engineering, all that actually matters to me 
is that it works.

there's so many angles to lies, and probably the most interesting fact to 
my recollection and in my opinion was that cops who thought that they were 
good at detecting lies actually did worse than chance when studied. i feel 
like the dunning kruger effect applies to this, where your confidence at 
some point is inversely proportional to your skill. there is no skill in 
lie detection, as the best lie detectors apparently score hardly better 
than chance, and the people who claim to be the best do worse than chance.
in another interesting example of lie detection there is a video of 
subjects who are lying about some things, not lying about others. they use 
several computerized methods of lie detection on the subject. it has been 
some time since i read this, but it was i believe 20% better than chance 
detection. and this was everything... like tone of voice, facial twitches, 
 and heart rate. i feel like their confirmation bias should have had the 
program to do better than that hehe.
a lot of this was covered in an introduction to criminal psychology lecture 
that i listened to on my commute. at least i think that was where i heard 
it.

About that hologramm thingi: Those are highly hypothetical scenarios but

that proof doesn't necessarily mean 100% true. And I also realize that 
science HAS been, and most likely always will he, wrong more often than it 
is right. So to just say something is true because science says so is 
retarded.﻿

Also many problems science has can be solved by assuming the universe is a 
hologram, or that it is a computer simulation by a much more advanced 
species. And the hologram idea is getting more and more plausible all the 
time as more studies/experiments are done. ﻿

And as I like to say(as others have) blindly believing in science makes it 
nothing more than a persons religion. I love science, I really do, but it 
can kill you. Look at the cholesterol and saturated fat science. For 6 
decades or more we have been told they are the devil, and carbs are good. 
Now after millions of people dieing and billions suffering from diseases 
that we now know comes from carbs, New studies are showing that cholesterol 
is good for us(especially women over 50) and a group of studies covering 41 
European countries shows that the more saturated fat you eat the lower your 
coronary heart disease(the WHO released those studies as a collection)
And aluminum, which for a hundred years, we have been told was safe to cook 
out of, has now been shown to be a major(quite possibly the main) cause of

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
This point of light in the sky is
Earth as seen from the surface of Mars.
And this is Earth as seen from Saturn.
Here's an image taken only 45,000 kilometres away,
the famous Blue Marble. But what does
Earth really look like?
Well, it depends on how you define "look".

The word look comes from
the old Breton word "lagud",
mean eye, the human eye.

And that's part of the problem.
Images like this are based on light
humans can see. But we don't see

everything.
There's a fantastic episode of Radiolab that uses
sound to illustrate just how different other creature

visual spaces are from our our own.
When we talk about the way something
physically looks
we are talking about the visual perception of emitted
or reflected electromagnetic radiation.
Specifically, visible light.
Light we perceive as red has a longer wavelength

than blue or violet.
But what if I crank the wavelength
even shorter? Does it stop being light?
No, it just becomes light
you can't see - ultraviolet, X-rays,

gamma rays.
Going the other way, you get infrared,
microwaves and finally, radio waves.
In principle, the spectrum of possible
electromagnetic wavelengths is infinite.
But even within the range of wavelengths we observe,
the breadth is breathtaking. If the entire
practical spectrum of wavelengths was laid out

linearly from New York to Los Angeles,
the visual portion we see
would only be the size of
100 nanometers. Small enough
to slip through a surgical mask. Point is,
when it comes to what their is to see, our
eyes miss out on lot. For instance,

take a look a remote control.
Many of  these things communicate with light
of wavelengths we can't see but mobile phone cameras

can. Try this at home. Push a button on a
remote control and you won't see much

but use a mobile phone camera
to detect wavelengths you can't see

and have them rendered visible.
There's a whole lot going on
we miss out on. Our night sky is full of
frequencies we can't see with our eyes alone
but Chromoscope.net allows you to extend

your vision.
This is the Milky Way as we see it,
the visible light it gives off. But slide

to see how it would look if our eyes
sensed other frequencies.

Of course, we are having to represent
these other frequencies

with visible colours because even
electromagnetic pretend time
is bounded by our puny limits.

As for Earth, if we only saw infrared
frequencies it might look something

like this in our minds.
Ultraviolet and extreme

ultraviolet vision would return
unrecognizable spheres.

With X-ray vision auroras around the
poles would shine brightly

and gamma ray vision would give
Earth a bright edge

from high-energy electromagnetic
radiation hitting the atmosphere
at a shallow angle.
So, which view is correct? Is there an
absolute true appearance of the Earth?
We haven't even started yet.

Look back at the Blue Marble.
What's with the tyranny
of "north" meaning "up"? Perhaps,
it's because we often equate "up" with "better"

and many early map makers were from
North of the equator.
But upside-down maps are equally true,

no matter how strange day may seem to us.
Funny enough,

the famous Blue Marble itself is a
product of North equals
up bias. It didn't originally look like this.
The crew of Apollo 17 originally took it
like this. NASA rotated it to
fit our traditional idea of up after the fact.

Here's a visual birth that comes from
the US Naval Observatory's live

animation of our planet.
You can see exactly what parts are

in its shadow at this very moment.
Other shadows fall
on Earth as well, like the Moon's shadow.

Last week @BadAstronomer shared this
image. The dark smudges on the left is
actually
the Moon's shadow during a Solar Eclipse

as seen from above Earth.
There's another problem with
the Blue Marble - it's flat and the Earth

is three-dimensional.
A  globe is the best way to represent the Earth

but globes are difficult to carry around
and even when displayed in two
dimensions,
well, you just can't see everything at once.
A flat map of the Earth is really convenient
but requires projecting a globe onto something

flat. And a sphere's surface cannot be
represented on a plane

without distortion.
The West Wing famously pointed out
the limitations of flat maps.
There's no such thing as a perfect flat map of the entire

world. Some maps are useful for some
things and other maps for other things
but it is really fun to pick on the Mercator projection,

mainly because it's so popular and is
even used by Google Maps,
mainly because it's so easy to zoom in on.
It preserves shape decently well but suffers
when it comes to area. As I've shown before, Africa

is huge. Its area is so large the
entire contiguous United States could
fit inside of it, along with all of China,
India, Japan and much of Europe.
But on the Mercator projection scale near the poles
is pretty wonky, distorted, which means
Greenland appears to be as large as Africa,
even though in reality it is only 1/14th
the size. There's more.

Check out Alaska and Brazil on a
Mercator projection. They appear almost
the same size but in reality Brazil
is nearly five times bigger than Alaska.
Areas near the equator are minimized, whereas
areas closer to the poles are exaggerated.
To have fun with this problem, play the Google Maps

Mercator puzzle. The red pieces are
countries projected outside of their
usual
locations. Now, what the heck is this

weird shape? Well, let's pull it away from
the North Pole, where scale is distorted
a lot
and now it's Australia.

You can see how the math behind map
projections distort Earth
by interacting with them on Jason Davies'

brilliant site. Notice how small
Greenland appears on the Mercator
projection when pulled down to the

equator and how exaggerated it becomes 
when moved to the edge.
To be fair, the Mercator projection is great for navigation.

If you want something that is more fair
when it comes to area,
try the Gall–Peters. Here,
landmasses are the right relative size
but shape is sacrificed. Everything looks a bit
too narrow.
Enter the Mollweide. This projection shows
equal areas and is a bit more pleasant shape-wise.

If you interrupt the Mollweide around
the oceans, relative area is preserved
and the shape of land masses becomes even more

accurate. When it comes to the shortest
route between two places on the surface
of the Earth, Gnomonic projections are really cool.

Every straight line journey taken on
Earth's surface is actually part of a great
circle. On Mercator projections actual straight line paths
look curved. But every straight line
on a Gnomonic projection is also a straight line
in real life - the shortest route. If you want

a compromise between shape and area,
you might try the pleasant

Winkel tripel, which the
National Geographic Society has used for maps it
produces
since 1998. Or a beautiful butterfly map

that could be a ball until it's
flattened, say, under a pane
of glass. The Dymaxion map can unfold
to show how nearly connected Earth's landmasses
are. It's a great way to visualize human migration
overtime. It's quite impressive how far and wide

humans have traveled on earth,
but it remains a bit of a disappointment
to realize just how narrow our slice
of visual perception really is.

But don't feel bad.
This brings us to the story of
Julian Bayliss.
Yes, hello, is this doctor Julian Bayliss?
[ON THE PHONE:] Yes, speaking.

Bayliss told me about how
one day, while using Google Earth, he
spotted some dark green vegetation.

It looked like a rain forest.
An expedition was scheduled
and it turned out to be just that - a rain forest
we had previously never seen. I asked him more.
So, what have you found there?

[ON THE PHONE:]
That day we found about 12 new species

just from Mabu.
So we found about 3 snakes, 2 chameleons and
about 4 butterflies, 2 new species of plants

and we've only really just been into the
forest edge. So, I read, read a paper

the other day, a scientific paper.
They estimate that there's maybe 8 million,

8.5 million species in this world
but we've only actually discovered
1.5 million or between 1.5 and 2 million.
So, we've actually only discovered maybe one fist of everything that's living on this
planet.
Wow, our eyes only see
a tiny fraction of what there is to see.
But within that tiny fraction there are still

an enormous number of things left to find.
So keep searching, keep looking.

[ON THE PHONE:]
And as always,
thanks for watching.
